channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Militants Kill Soldiers in Algeria
item.description: Qaeda-affiliated fighters ambushed military forces east of the capital, killing at least 14 soldiers.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Doris Pilkington Garimara, Novelist, Is Dead at 76
item.description: Ms. Garimara was best known for her 1996 novel “Follow the Rabbit-Proof Fence,” which helped awaken Australians to the plight of the Aborigines and was later made into a film.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: U.S. Promotes Network to Foil Digital Spying
item.description: The State Department and other agencies are spending millions to finance local systems, known as mesh networks, as more secure alternatives to the Internet.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and JAMES GLANZ
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wireless routers attached to rooftops in Sayada form a local network that the developers say is more secure than the Internet.

item.title: John Shirley-Quirk, Bass-Baritone, Is Dead at 82
item.description: Mr. Shirley-Quirk was a British chemistry teacher who almost by accident became a world-renowned bass-baritone and made 30 appearances at the Met between 1974 and 1991.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Photos Link Masked Men in East Ukraine to Russia
item.description: Descriptions from eastern Ukraine endorsed by the Obama administration suggest many of the mysteriously well-armed gunmen there are Russian military and intelligence forces.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS, MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Aracataca Journal: Magic Ebbs From Colombian Town That Informed an Author’s Work
item.description: For Gabriel García Márquez, Aracataca served as the model for the fictitious town of Macondo in “One Hundred Years of Solitude.” For Cataqueros, it serves as home.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Ukrainian Gas Broker Faces Scrutiny
item.description: Dmytro Firtash has made billions brokering gas deals, but he now faces both a criminal indictment and a racketeering lawsuit in United States courts.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Dmytro Firtash, right, has been accused of laundering money through deals that benefited an aide to Viktor Yanukovych.

item.title: A War Shrine Gesture in Japan Complicates Relations in Asia
item.description: The prime minister, Shinzo Abe, sent a traditional offering to a shrine honoring Japan’s war dead, a move that may anger South Korea and China.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Errors Mounted as Chaos Ruled Capsizing Ferry
item.description: A portrait of chaos is emerging from crew members, survivors and a transcript of the vessel’s final 40 minutes of communications with emergency dispatchers.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN, KIRK SEMPLE and SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:description: The Coast Guard of South Korea carried a victim of the ferry disaster on Sunday. Sixty-one people are confirmed dead.

item.title: Yemen Strikes Hit Qaeda Camps
item.description: One Yemeni official said the militants targeted in the attacks were among the “leading and dangerous” elements of Al Qaeda.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: After Everest Disaster, Sherpas Contemplate Strike
item.description: As the Sherpas, who put themselves at great risk to guide affluent clients up Mount Everest, mulled an unprecedented strike, some would-be climbers said their passion for the ascent was gone.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and GRAHAM BOWLEY
item.media:credit: Rajneesh Bhandari for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kaji Sherpa, 39, at a hospital in Katmandu, Nepal. He said he would not climb Everest again.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Clues to Family’s Business Ties Found in Public Paper Trail
item.description: Documenting the Zhou family investment tree to assess the vast wealth accumulated by the family of the former national security chief, who also ran the giant China National Petroleum Corp.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE, CHRIS BUCKLEY and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A web of intrigue surrounds China's investigation into the former security chief Zhou Yongkang and his family. Curious Chinese have started to visit his home village of Xiqiantou in eastern China, peeking inside his brothers' houses and snapping pictures at the Zhou family's ancestral grave.

item.title: Jose Carlos Bergantiños Diaz, Suspect in Art Swindle, Is Arrested in Spain
item.description: An art dealer was taken into custody in connection with a swindle that led collectors to spend more than $80 million on phony masterworks. The United States is expected to request his extradition.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

item.title: A Lead Grows, but Runoff Is Likely in Afghan Race
item.description: The candidate Abdullah Abdullah widened his lead, but neither of the top contenders seemed to be on track to win more than 50 percent of the vote.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Kabul bearing the image of Abdullah Abdullah, who has 44.4 percent of the vote so far in the Afghan presidential race. He is followed by Ashraf Ghani, who has 33.2 percent.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The April Invasion of Veracruz
item.description: In 1914, the people of the city, left to their own devices, defied a U.S. force sent to teach Mexico some lessons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Jet Makes Emergency Landing
item.description: The plane returned safely to Kuala Lumpur after blowing a tire on the main landing gear during takeoff.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS

item.title: Breaking Proud Tradition, Captains Flee and Let Others Go Down With Ship
item.description: Lee Jun-seok became the second sea captain in two years to flee a sinking vessel when he left a South Korean ferry as terrified passengers were still struggling to get off.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Lee Jun-seok, in mask, the second captain in two years to flee a sinking vessel, was later arrested.

item.title: Shootout Underscores Fragile Truce in Ukraine
item.description: At least three people were killed Sunday at a checkpoint run by pro-Russian militants near the town of Slovyansk in eastern Ukraine, days after a settlement was reached calling on insurgents to disarm.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators inspected two burned vehicles on Sunday after a shootout at a checkpoint run by pro-Russian militants near the town of Slovyansk.

item.title: More Than 40 People Killed in Bus Accident in Pakistan
item.description: At least 42 people, including 13 children, were killed after a bus collided with a trailer truck in southern Pakistan in one of the nation’s worst traffic accidents in years, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Rescue workers attempting to pull passengers out of a bus after a deadly collision with a trailer truck on Sunday in the Sukkur district of southern Sindh Province.

item.title: Fractured State of Pakistani Taliban Calls Peace Deal Into Question
item.description: Infighting between commanders appears to be impeding talks with government negotiators, and recent bombings raise the possibility that the very idea of making peace has divided the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Divers Begin Bringing Bodies Out of Capsized Ferry
item.description: As the death toll from the South Korean disaster reached 58, with more than 200 people still missing, officials said they expected weeks of grim recovery operations.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:description: Rescue workers moved the bodies of victims from Jindo-port on Jindo Island on Sunday.

item.title: Battle Rages in Homs, Hub of Revolt Against Assad Government
item.description: Syrian insurgents and antigovernment activists are reporting near-continuous bombardment of the Old City and the nearby neighborhood of Waer.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Security personnel and onlookers gathered Monday after a car bomb was detonated in Homs. Another went off on Friday.

item.title: U.N. Struggles to Stem Haiti Cholera Epidemic
item.description: The United Nations, facing a shortage of supplies to handle the epidemic, refuses to address whether its peacekeepers brought a deadly strain of the disease into the country.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Jacob Birnbaum, Champion of Soviet Jews, Dies at 88
item.description: Inspired by the civil rights movement, Mr. Birnbaum aimed at improving the lives of Soviet Jews and he contributed to legislation that eventually helped liberalize Moscow’s emigration policies.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Militant Group Says It Bombed Nigerian City
item.description: Islamic extremists claimed responsibility for an explosion that ripped through a busy bus station in Abuja, killing at least 75 people and wounding 141.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
